repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->
Similiarly to #28807 lsp diagnostics are hard to read when containing multiple whitespace.
Very simple example in Haskell:
Before
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b3a6a9fd-3b9d-41a0-a7e1-979a7a3a8db4)
After
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/790a3ce0-ca5a-454a-9110-b9262680ae6a)

This pull request fixes the issue by adding a default formatting function to replace multiple whitespace with a single space.
For users who added a custom format function nothing will change. Only the default is changed to be more sane.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
I don't understand this to be honest - wouldn't it make sense to provide a *usable* default to all users and make them override the behaviour to something less sensible or personally fitting? I think this is an actual improvement, in all cases.   

Displaying all the whitespace that were intended for editors that don't make the same design decision as neovim in displaying the diagnostics on a single line makes the user experience worse in all cases.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
> The purpose of having a `format` option is exactly for scenarios like this.

It's for overriding the default, to avoid special-case flags.

But if can present stuff better by default, why not? Assuming it doesn't regress some other common case.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
Because if a server sends us a message we should display it as is. If a server (why change the default for something specific to the Haskell LSP?) has a funky behavior then the format function is there to massage the input into whatever users prefer.

Go ahead if you want to reopen this PR and merge it, but I’m very much against it. I’ll let @gpanders and @lewis6991 weigh in too.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
> Because if a server sends us a message we should display it as is.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but aren't we already removing `\n` from the text?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
> has a funky behavior then the format function is there to massage the input


The server does something totally sensible for multiline displaying, it uses newlines and indents the next line. 

> Correct me if I'm wrong, but aren't we already removing \n from the text

when I checked, at least the ^@ didn’t show up, so presumably, but maybe the multiple white spaces that stem from the indentation of the next line should still be contracted?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
I agree with @MariaSolOs , we should avoid adding workarounds to patch up issues in one server. This “solves” the immediate problem with Haskell, but who is to say it doesn’t introduce a problem somewhere else?

Our policy has always been to stick to the specification as written, allowing user customization where possible, and pressure upstream servers to fix their bugs rather than work around them.

> The server does something totally sensible for multiline displaying, it uses newlines and indents the next line.

Nvim can handle multi line diagnostics so why is the Haskell language server collapsing it into a single line? For virtual text we show only the first line of a multiline diagnostic, but all lines are visible in virtual lines or when opening a floating window.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body: If Haskell language server is collapsing lines then that should also be applying this transformation. I assumed Nvim was stripping newlines for virtual text. We should certainly not be normalizing whitespace to account for servers sending badly formatted text.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
> > Because if a server sends us a message we should display it as is.
> 
> Correct me if I'm wrong, but aren't we already removing `\n` from the text?

Yes, depending on the nature of the transformation, we must decide which parts should be literal and which should fit into our presentation. 

idk which case applies to this PR, but the distinction matters. If we can present things better in our UI without regressing, then we should.

If this case is an isolated LS bug, then this PR probably is out of scope.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1696,9 +1696,10 @@ M.handlers.virtual_text = {
     end
 
     if opts.virtual_text then
-      if opts.virtual_text.format then
-        diagnostics = reformat_diagnostics(opts.virtual_text.format, diagnostics)
+      local default_format = function(diagnostic)
